awd_titl_txt: Achievement in STEM through a Program of Immersive Research Experiences and Support
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, this project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Fordham College at Rose Hill (FCRH).  This project will respond to the urgent national need for a talented and diverse STEM workforce by increasing the persistence and graduation rates of students who enter college with an interest in STEM.  Over the next five years, this project will directly support 60 to 100 academically-talented FCRH students.  (The number of Scholars that can be supported depends on the level of the Scholars' financial need.) By completing a robust research plan, this project should increase understanding about which interventions best support student success, for whom they work, and under what circumstances are they most effective. The investigators will share their findings broadly to encourage others to learn from the results obtained through this research project. 

This project will enroll five cohorts of 12-20 academically-talented incoming FCRH first-year STEM majors. Students who are selected will have significant financial need and include individuals from traditionally under-represented backgrounds in STEM, including women, under-represented minorities, students with disabilities, students who are the first in their families to go to college, and students from educationally-disadvantaged backgrounds. During their first year, these students will be awarded scholarships of up to $10,000 to reduce their otherwise unmet financial need. In addition, they will participate in a coordinated offering of three high-impact practices designed to support their success in STEM:  1) A pre-enrollment summer academic and career-focused orientation program; 2) A year-long Introduction to Research course that will engage students in original research; and 3) A full-time summer research internship. After the first year, continuing scholarship recipients will engage in a fourth high-impact practice by serving as peer mentors for the remainder of their undergraduate studies and attending the program's community-building events. Few, if any, existing studies have investigated the impact of a multi-phasic, coordinated program on promoting STEM success. The project team will fill this gap by conducting a well-matched, quantitative/qualitative longitudinal analysis of attitudes that predispose students for STEM success, including self-efficacy, self-concept, science learner identity, and STEM career aspirations. This study will also examine academic metrics of success, including course grades, overall grade point average, and progress toward degree. In addition, the study will measure social belonging to assess the impact of this S-STEM program on students' STEM identity. By supporting diverse cohorts of students to graduation, this project will help to strengthen our nation's STEM workforce and, thus, enhance its competitiveness and preeminence in STEM fields. The knowledge gained from this project will inform the Fordham community and will be disseminated widely within the STEM education research community. The results are expected to be generalizable to other institutions that seek to surmount barriers to undergraduate student success in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The grant Achievement in STEM through a Program of Immersive Research Experiences and Support (ASPIRES) aimed to increase the retention and success of socioeconomically disadvantaged students pursuing STEM majors at Fordham College Rose Hill (FCRH), a college of Fordham University in the Bronx, NY. The program’s goal was to support academically talented first-year STEM students with unmet financial need, using a multi-faceted approach that combined high-impact practices, FCRH resources, and a dedicated team of faculty, staff, and administrative colleagues. ASPIRES provided activities that offered academic support, research awareness, and community-building during the summer after accepting admission to Fordham through the summer following their first year. Tuition scholarships to these students, termed ASPIRES Scholars, were provided by the NSF S-STEM grant for the first year, with subsequent years funded by Fordham.

Key elements of the ASPIRES program included (1) an intensive program for Scholars bridging the summer between high school and college which introduced them to STEM disciplines, research opportunities, academic support, and the first year "hidden curriculum", (2) an academic year seminar that built on the summer program and introduced STEM research through literature, faculty and student talks, and developing prospective research projects, and (3) an optional funded summer research experience with a faculty mentor. Five Scholar cohorts were funded, representing the matriculation years 2019 to 2023.

Outcomes

The ASPIRES program supported nearly 70 socioeconomically disadvantaged students, with greater than 80% retained through to graduation. Students had an average expected family contribution (EFC) to tuition of a little under $6K, nearly 70% were Pell eligible and approximately 60% were first-generation. The program distributed an average award of just under $9K per student, with most receiving $10K annually. The cohort was demographically diverse, with over 30% identifying as Latino and approximately 75% female. The optional summer research opportunity had significant participation. 

The academic standing of retained Scholars remained comparatively stable from the end of the first year of college (GPA 3.34) throughout the last attending year. Biological sciences was the most common major (42% after the first year), followed by computer science (18%). The proportion of students in STEM majors decreased slightly over time, with a notable shift to “other” non-STEM majors (16%) after year 1. Of 24 students who reached graduation at the time of this report, approximately 50% continued in STEM education, 25% pursued healthcare careers, and 25% entered non-STEM fields.

Retention rates were compared across several undergraduate groups: Scholars, an introductory chemistry course control group, all STEM majors, and first-generation and Pell recipients. Scholars generally had higher retention rates, although small sample sizes limited broader generalizations. Preliminary results suggest that participants remain in STEM majors at comparable or higher rates than other groups. The analysis also revealed that Scholars consistently exhibited higher STEM retention through their junior year. Graduates showed comparable persistence to the chemistry control group. Resilience, self-efficacy, and sense of belonging were robust in ASPIRES students and were similar to the chemistry comparison group.

The optional summer research experience showed that the program supported 28 undergraduate scholars and their faculty mentors in completing research projects in chemistry, computer science, biology, neuroscience/psychology, and physics. Scholars averaged 33 hours per week on their projects. Most worked full-time, with a smaller proportion working part-time (10 hours per week). Mentors reported positive experiences, with 75% of scholars "strongly agreeing" that their mentors were helpful. Overall program satisfaction was high, with 75% of participants "extremely satisfied."

Intellectual Merit

The outcomes demonstrate ASPIRES’ effectiveness in retaining socioeconomically disadvantaged students in STEM majors and fields, with strong academic results, meaningful financial support, and impactful research opportunities. The summer research program provided Scholars with valuable research experience and fostered collaboration between Scholars and mentors. While challenges related to retention and shifting academic interests after the first year remain, the program’s success is evident in its positive academic outcomes and mentor-mentee collaborations.

Broader Impacts

ASPIRES identified low-income students with a desire to pursue a STEM degree and supported them from the start of college through the summer after their first year. Over 75% of recent graduates pursued post-baccalaureate careers in STEM and/or healthcare. The program’s first year STEM bridge, seminar, and optional summer research experiences are new STEM initiatives at Fordham, with potential for broader institutional adoption. Nearly 30 faculty members mentored ASPIRES students, and the program also engaged other Fordham faculty and staff in STEM and non-STEM areas.

These efforts, focused on low-income and underrepresented students, have fostered a strong sense of identity and empowerment in the participants. ASPIRES graduates mentored subsequent cohorts, participated in peer tutoring, and served as role models for other socioeconomically disadvantaged students. This engagement contributes to the success of Fordham’s increasingly diverse student body and inspires students to pursue success in STEM majors, with long-lasting benefits for both students and the broader academic community of faculty and staff.
